title: Didot italic (1783)
content:
This is from an essay by Firmin Didot published in 1783 and set in his Cicero italic (12 point) - a text where, supposedly, Firmin shows his mother the peculiarities of the typeface. There's an interesting treatment of the lowercase v - when paired with a, like in the word "avez", it gets a different shape. Like this:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535im_/http:/typophile.com/files/didot_italic01_5394.jpg)

The v in "vous" is the standard shape; the one in "avez" is the contextual glyph, narrower and without the left top tail. The reason seems to be having an homogeneous kerning. I wonder if other typographers ever applied such a trick. Below is attached the full page from the Italic essay.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [didot\_italic02.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535/http:/typophile.com/files/didot_italic02_0.jpg) | 349.47 KB |
author: ncaleffi

comments.content:
<cite>The v in "vous" is the standard shape;</cite>

In that text, the v in "vous" is used only in initial position.

"In that text, the v in "vous" is used only in initial position."

Correct! So in Didot's intention the "contextual" lowercase v glyph was probably the first letter in a word; indeed, the narrow v is also used in other words:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535im_/http:/typophile.com/files/didot_italic03_6028.jpg)
Contextual type was common at that time. The short and long s would be a more common example.

Clearly informed from calligraphic tendencies.

I don't have the original scans of the document handy, but here is a sample from one of my fonts:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535im_/http:/typophile.com/files/vouz_6112.png)

_I wonder if other typographers ever applied such a trick._

I do.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535im_/http:/typophile.com/files/gabverve_6727.gif)

Tim Ahrens’s Lapture includes contextualization of diagonal l.c. letters as well, but in a more subtle fashion (as with John’s) and focused on the right side, rather than the left.

John Downer’s Paperback also has contextualized alt l.c. diagonals for specific situations.

When I was talking to the late Kay Amert, she said that I should look at the italics of Simon de Colines because they were full of contextual and alternative glyphs. I have yet to do this but I expect that she is right about this. However I will be looking at them quite soon to see if they bear on my work.

In the meantime here are my contextual v shapes from my not yet released Reading MATD type - Arrotino.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535im_/http:/typophile.com/files/v_4203.gif)

The blue portion at the serifs is the portion contextually removed. The middle one has a bit of both sides removed because it has two diagonal neighbors and the ones on the left and right just the the side next to a diagonal letter. All the diagonals in Arrotino roman have this behaviour when set against a fellow diagonal (y, v, w and x). The idea is to be able to present the letter optimally in all contexts. The example shown is unlikely to be a final solution for this letter as it was put together fairly quickly - more in order to test the code to control it than as a matter of highly deliberate letter design. Still, could a little thing like that make a difference? I think it can - yes.
Subtle! And this is intended for text sizes, right?

That's pretty darn subtle, Eben, to the degree that I wonder whether it might be simpler to make these shorter serif v glyphs the default letter and dispense with the broader ones altogether. I had a similar thought regarding Rob's Vesper alternates, but they are not nearly as subtle as yours.

<cite>That's pretty darn subtle</cite>

Didot was was much less subtle indeed, so much so that when I look at a "v" in initial position (using Linotype Didot), I get the feeling that a big chunk is missing.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20111216182535im_/http:/typophile.com/files/verve_4320.jpg)

I'm thinking about doing something a bit like this Didot _v_ in my Brill Italic typeface. The style is derived -- more directly than most types -- from 18th century formal cursive writing, but I'm forced to make a pointed rather than a rounded _v_ because the rounded form is a separate letter in IPA and some orthographies. My default _v_ is quite similar to the Didot initial form, which of course causes spacing or collision problems when following some other letters. I probably won't use the variant form after every letter, though, only after those in which problems occur.
